newsitem.title: PAKISTAN: Pakistan forex reserves seen swelling by December.
newsitem.headline: Pakistan forex reserves seen swelling by December.

text.p: Pakistan's liquid foreign reserves, now at $670 million, could reach $1 billion by December, despite a widening trade gap and a cut in the country's credit ratings, analysts and bankers said on Thursday.
"Pakistan will be able to manage to raise the cash reserves up to the $1 billion mark by December," analyst Nauman Sheikh of KASB & Co predicted.
Foreign reserves, excluding gold and special drawing rights, fell to $573 million on October 31, but jumped to $670 million on November 7. Bankers expect the upward trend to continue.

"Though the interbank forex market is short of dollars and the trade deficit is alarming, restoration of investor confidence has resulted in forex inflows from abroad," said one foreign banker, who asked not to be named.
Battered Pakistani markets have taken some heart from the November 5 dismissal by President Farooq Leghari of Benazir Bhutto, who was replaced by Meraj Khalid as interim premier.

The foreign banker said economic and political uncertainty in September and October had prompted individuals to withdraw an estimated $200 million from forex bank accounts, sending the six-month forward dollar premium to a record 0.76 rupee.
The premium has since dropped to the 0.50 to 0.65 rupee range, he said.

The chief forex dealer at a local bank said the government had attracted an estimated $150 million from some Middle East-based banks, out of which $75 million had already been placed in a special deposit of the central bank.

In October, Muhammad Yaqub, governor of the State (central) Bank of Pakistan, offered a 17 percent annual return to banks bringing in foreign currency deposits from abroad in an effort to replenish depleting reserves.
He said banks could get the 17 percent return on the rupee equivalent of foreign currency they deposited in a special central bank account between October 22 and November 28.

Bankers said foreign banks had told the central bank they would bring in about $350 million to exploit the offer, but the commitments shrank to $150 million after Moody's Investors Services Inc cut Pakistan's credit ratings on November 6.
"The downgrading was a major shock to all foreign banks operating in Pakistan," one banker said. It had made it harder to arrange forex deposits for Pakistan in markets abroad.
He said the downgrade had slowed inflows into the central bank's special account, but added that local banks were trying to bring in around $50 million to benefit from the high yield.
Sheikh said resumption of a stalled $600 million standby loan from the International Monetary Fund, on which an agreement is expected soon, would boost confidence in Pakistan's finances.

"We think if Pakistan gets the $160 million in the two delayed tranches of the standby loan and some progress is made on negotiations for a new extended structural adjustment facility, things will start looking better," Sheikh said.

Analyst Amir Peracha said the trade deficit, which surged to a provisional $443 million in September from $264 million in October, was likely to start narrowing from November as the impact of the latest rupee devaluation begins to show.
The central bank knocked 7.86 percent off the rupee's dollar value on October 22. It has kept the rate unchanged since then.
